texts.name: Roman d'Alexandre
texts.overview: Roman d'Alexandre; Alexander and Dindimus (Alexander Fragment B) in Middle English verse (fols 209r-215v); Marco Poloâ€™s Li Livres du Graunt Caam, in French prose (fols 218r-71v)
texts.compilationDate: A colophon (fol. 208r) reveals that the main text was completed on 18 December 1338 and the illumination completed in 1345 by the Flemish illuminator, Jehan de Grise, and members of his workshop. Anglo-Norman rubrics were subsequently added to the manuscript, perhaps in England, as well asthe two further texts.

texts.name: Roman d'Alexandre
texts.shelfmark: Edinburgh, National Library of Scotland, MS Advocates' 19.2.2 (2)
texts.overview: This manuscript originally contained John Barbour's Bruce and Hary's Wallace - the two texts have since been separated
texts.adaptation: Adaptation (parts of the Scots text show influence of the French romance): VI.516-26; VIII.480; XI.341-4

texts.name: Roman d'Alexandre
texts.shelfmark: Survives uniquely in a printed edition of c. 1580 by the Edinburgh printer, Alexander Arbuthnot (STC 321.5). Only copy said to be owned by Earl of Dalhousie but actual whereabouts currently uncertain.
texts.overview: Print contains only the Octosyllabic Alexander
texts.adaptation: Translation and adaptation into octosyllabic couplets of two episodes within the Roman d'Alexandre: Le Fuerre de Gadres and Les Voeux du Paon
texts.integrated: The two translations are combined to form the one Scots romance: The Buik of Alexander.

texts.name: Roman d'Alexandre
texts.compilationPlace: Uncertain, but perhaps connected to seat of the Campbell of Glenorchy family
texts.adaptation: Translation and Adaptation of part of the Roman d'Alexandre by Sir Gilbert Hay to form his (decasyllabic) Buik of King Alexander the Conquerour
texts.integrated: Yes: Sir Gilbert Hay's Buik of King Alexander the Conquerour
texts.fragment: Almost complete (acephalous in both surviving witnesses)

texts.name: Kyng Alisaunder
texts.adaptation: Middle English verse translation of Anglo-Norman romance: adaptive
texts.fragment: All Middle English: Lybeaus Desconus; Merlyn; Kyng Alisaunder; Seege of Troy;  Piers Plowman (A text)

texts.name: Kyng Alisaunder
texts.adaptation: Middle English verse translation of Anglo-Norman romance: adaptive
texts.integrated: National Library of Scotland, MS Advocates 19.2.1, fols. 278r-279r (plus fragments)
texts.fragment: Large collection of English verse, particularly romances: small amount of Anglo-Norman

texts.name: Kyng Alisaunder
texts.adaptation: Middle English verse translation of Anglo-Norman romance: adaptive
texts.integrated: Oxford, Bodleian Library MS. Laud Misc. 622, fols.27v-64r
texts.fragment: English verse, including material from South English Legendary, Life of St Alexis, Siege of Jerusalem

texts.name: Alexandreis
texts.fragment: Latin poetry of the later 12th century, including Joseph of Exeter's Ylias, John of Hauville's Architrenius, Seneca, Tragedies

texts.name: Roman d'Alexandre
texts.integrated: Oxford, Bodleian Library MS Bodley 264, fols. 3r-208r
texts.fragment: Roman d'Alexandre, Alexander and Dindimus (Alexander Fragment B: English), Li Livres du Graunt Caam (French prose)
